bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to John B. Hartzell, August 26, 1940

div1.p: Hench requests information on the Dean Memorial Bridge.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to John B. Hartzell, August 26, 1940
div1.opener:
August 26, 1940
Dr. John Hartzell
7815 E. Jefferson Ave.
Detroit, Michigan
My dear John:
div1.p:
It was indeed nice to see you and Esther. Permit me
to send you the memorandum regarding the information I requested.

In 1900, Walter Reed and three other members of the U.S.
Army Yellow Fever Board carried on experiments to determine the cause of yellow
fever in Cuba. Volunteers were inoculated by infected mosquitos. The first to
come down was Dr. Carroll, the next was an army private, William H. Dean, who
developed experimental yellow fever and survived. Later with others his name was
put on the Army Honor Roll. I understand that in his latter years he lived in
Detroit and that there was a bridge named after him there--the Dean Memorial
Bridge. I should like to verify this and if possible (if it doesn't cost too
much) get a photograph of the bridge and the memorial tablet which I suppose
will be on it. I hate to bother you with this, but in October I am reading
a paper on the conquest of yellow fever on the occasion of the dedication of
the Lazear Memorial, and am most anxious to have this dope. Perhaps the post
master would know where this bridge is if nobody else would, or the city
engineer.
Thank you so much for your help.
div1.closer: Sincerely, P. S. Hench, M. D. psh:ds
